attributes.title: Replication of Griskevicius, V., Tybur, J.M., & Van den Bergh, B. (2010) at Concordia College
attributes.description: Recreating the experiment of Griskevicius et al. to check reproducibility of results and provide stronger evidence for application to diverse groups of subjects through a research methods psychology class.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

q1.value: The influence of personality on the effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension and the literary experience of reading narrative texts

q2.value: Annika Schwabe, Lukas Brandl, Günther Stocker, Hajo Boomgaarden

q3.value: There is no evidence that the reading device influences the reading comprehension when reading a narrative text. However, there are hardly any studies analyzing other dimensions of reading narrative texts. Further, there are almost no studies taking individual factors, such as personality and attitudes towards technology, into account when analyzing the difference between analog and digital reading of narrative texts. Therefore, we examine if there are any individual differences influencing the cognitive and emotional aspects of reading narrative text when reading in a printed book or reading the same text on an e-reader.

q4.value:
H1: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by personality.
H1.1: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by openness to experience.
H1.2: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by conscientiousness.
H1.3: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by extraversion.
H1.4: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by agreeableness.
H1.5: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by neuroticism.

H2: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the attitude towards technology.
H2.1: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the optimism in relation to technology.
H2.2: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the innovativeness in relation to technology.
H2.3: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the discomfort in relation to technology.
H2.4: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the insecurity in relation to technology.
H2.5: The effect of the reading device on different dimensions of the reading experience while reading a narrative text is influenced by the attitude towards digital reading.


H3: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by personality.
H3.1: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by openness to experience.
H3.2: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by conscientiousness.
H3.3: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by extraversion.
H3.4: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by agreeableness.
H3.5: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by neuroticism.


H4: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the attitude towards technology.
H4.1: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the optimism in relation to technology.
H4.2: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the innovativeness in relation to technology.
H4.3: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the discomfort in relation to technology.
H4.4: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the insecurity in relation to technology.
H4.5: The effect of the reading device on the reading comprehension of a narrative text is influenced by the attitude towards digital reading.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The subjects will not know about the purpose of this study.

question.value: An unpaired between subjects design with two groups (analog reading vs. digital reading).

q9.value: Simple randomization. Test IDs were randomly assigned to one of the two conditions and test IDs were blindly given to the particpants.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: We have already started collecting the data, but have not accessed it in any form. We are still in the planned data collection process and do not collect additional data. The data for this study is part of a bigger data collection process. For another study, we will use this data for, we preregistered the data collection process and planned sample size before we started the data collection process (https://osf.io/vqkc4).

question.value: Participants are recruited through posters and flyers at bookshops, at libraries, and at venues for public readings, via social media, and word-of-mouth advertising. Participants are paid 20€ for their participation. Participants must be at least 18 years old, German native speakers or with a high level of proficiency in German, and interested in reading fictional books.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants.

q14.value: The sample size is an arbitrary number because we do not have any reference for the effect size.

q15.value: Due to full lab schedules, we are only able to test for four months. Therefore, we have to stop testing after these four months, even if we did not reach our target sample of 200 participants.

question.value: Reading device: the participants will read the same text either in a printed book or using an e-reader

We will measure the literary reading experience with the “Aspekte des Leseerlebens” scale by Appel et al. (2002) and the “Narrative and Aesthetic Feelings” scale by Koopman (2015). 
Further, we will test reading comprehension, using a self-developed test consisting of 16 detailed multiple-choice questions with seven possible answers, with one of them “Not described in the text” and one “I don’t know”. 
Further, we will use the NEO-FFI-30 by Körner et al. (2008) to measure personality, the German version of the Technology Readiness Index scale (TRI 2.0) by Parasuraman & Colby (2015) (German translation provided by C.L. Colby) to measure attitude towards technology and a self-developed questionnaire exploring the attitude towards digital reading. This questionnaire consists of seven 5-point Likert scale items (see appendix).

Appel, M., Koch, E., Schreier, M., & Groeben, N. (2002). Aspekte des Leseerlebens: Skalenentwicklung. Zeitschrift für Medienpsychologie, 14, 149-154.
Koopman, E. M. E. (2015). How texts about suffering trigger reflection: Genre, personal factors, and affective responses. Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts, 9, 430-441.
Körner, A., Geyer, M., Roth, M., Drapeau, M., Schmutzer, G., Albani, C., ... & Brähler, E. (2008). Persönlichkeitsdiagnostik mit dem NEO-Fünf-Faktoren-Inventar: Die 30-Item-Kurzversion (NEO-FFI-30). PPmP-Psychotherapie· Psychosomatik· Medizinische Psychologie, 58, 238-245.
Parasuraman, A., & Colby, C. L. (2015). An updated and streamlined technology readiness index: TRI 2.0. Journal of service research, 18, 59-74.

Because the “Aspekte des Leseerlebens” scale by Appel et al. (2002) and the “Narrative and Aesthetic Feelings” scale by Koopman (2015) cover similar but not identical aspects of the reading experience we chose to use both instruments. However, to reduce the dimensions and to summarize similar items of two instruments, we will perform an exploratory factor analysis to find the latent factors. 

For the five factors of the NEO-FFI-30 and the four factors of the TRI 2.0, we will combine the items to factors as proposed by the authors and calculate a summary score. Nevertheless, by calculating Chronbach’s α for each factor we will check the internal consistency and exclude items in case the Cronbach’s α is below 0.65.
Further, we will also calculate a summary score for our reading comprehension test and attitude towards digital reading scale and also calculate the Chronbach’s α for the attitude towards digital reading scale and exclude items in case the Cronbach’s α is below 0.65.

To reduce the dimensions of the variable reading experience we will perform an explorative factor analysis with the items of the “Aspekte des Leseerlebens” scale and the “Narrative and Aesthetic Feelings” scale. We will use principal axis factor analysis for factor extraction. To determine the number of factors, we will use Horn's parallel analysis method to identify the right stopping criterion. Because we assume a correlation between the factors, we will further use an oblique promax rotation with Kappa = 4. The new factors will be named congruent with the content and items that do not match a factor will be excluded. For further analyses, we will then use the factor scores (regression method).

To test the hypotheses of the personality and the attitude towards technology moderating the effect of the reading medium on the reading experience and reading comprehension, we will conduct multiple multiple regression analyses. We will conduct separate multiple regression analyses with each factor of the reading experience and reading comprehension (as DV) and reading medium (as IV) and each of the five personality factors separately and each of the five attitude towards technology (as IV) separately.

q20.value: Additionally to the already described transformations, we will dummy code the Likert scales of NEO-FFI-30 and TRI 2.0 as described by the authors and dummy code the Likert scale of the attitudes towards digital reading scale.

q21.value: We will always use two-tailed tests with the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: We will exclude the data if the participant dropped out at any point of the experiment.

q23.value: We do not expect any missing data because the survey program does not allow to continue the survey if data points are missing. However, in case there are any missing data due to software problems, we will exclude this participant from the analysis of the part where data is missing but not from other analyses.

q25.value:
Appel, M., Koch, E., Schreier, M., & Groeben, N. (2002). Aspekte des Leseerlebens: Skalenentwicklung. Zeitschrift für Medienpsychologie, 14, 149-154.
Koopman, E. M. E. (2015). How texts about suffering trigger reflection: Genre, personal factors, and affective responses. Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts, 9, 430-441.
Körner, A., Geyer, M., Roth, M., Drapeau, M., Schmutzer, G., Albani, C., ... & Brähler, E. (2008). Persönlichkeitsdiagnostik mit dem NEO-Fünf-Faktoren-Inventar: Die 30-Item-Kurzversion (NEO-FFI-30). PPmP-Psychotherapie· Psychosomatik· Medizinische Psychologie, 58, 238-245.
Parasuraman, A., & Colby, C. L. (2015). An updated and streamlined technology readiness index: TRI 2.0. Journal of service research, 18, 59-74.

attributes.title: Age-related motives in volunteering
attributes.description: •	This research is important in order to understand the patterns of motivation concerning voluntary work. It should be examined whether motivation for voluntary work depends on age. Earlier results show that motivation for voluntary work is due to either egoistic or altruistic orientations (Bierhoff, 2018). Age may be an important factor for the kind of voluntary work.

q3.value: This research is important in order to understand the patterns of motivation concerning voluntary work. It should be examined whether motivation for voluntary work depends on age. Earlier results show that motivation for voluntary work is due to either egoistic or altruistic orientations (Bierhoff, 2018). Age may be an important factor for the kind of voluntary work.

q4.value:
•	It is hypothesized that elderly persons show more altruistic motives for voluntary work than younger people. Younger people have more egoistic motives. Younger people are more aware of developments and job recommendations than elderly people. 
1.	Elderly volunteers have more altruistic motives than younger volunteers.
2.	Younger volunteers have more egoistic motives than senior volunteers. 
3.	Younger volunteers think more about their career motivation when doing voluntary work than elderly people.
4.	Elderly people do voluntary work in order to compensate for their job(s) than younger people.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a questionnaire survey. Survey measures are altruistic and egoistic approaches to voluntary work in two age groups. Furthermore motives concerning the volunteers’ employment should be examined.  These scales will be presented in a random order. Only participants who are currently engaged in voluntary work will be asked.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: •	Participants will be recruited among non-profit organisations “Jugendring Dortmund”, among university students in Germany and via social networks. Psychology students will obtain credit points for their respective classes. We will create an online study using Qualtrics platform. With respect to eligibility, participants must be at least 18 years old, parental approval is not required. They must have been engaged in voluntary work for at least 6 months and volunteer once a month.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 84 participants. We will recruit up to 84 participants in order of a cooperation project with other students. Also we assuming that not all of them will finish the survey completely.

q14.value: Sample size computation: For difference between two independent means (t-test) based upon .8 statistical power, with error probability of .05, and an estimated medium effect size of .5. Using the G*power program, the required sample size is N = 102 (N = 51 for each group; one-tailed test).

q15.value: Data collection will be finished by 12th April 2020.

question.value:
Measures of study variables:
The „Skala zur Einstellungsstruktur ehrenamtlicher Helfer (SEEH)“ (Bierhoff et al., 2007) is used to asses altruistic versus egoistic dimensions in voluntary work. It is measured with 26 items on nine-point Likert scales. For indicating age differences in motivation, the volunteers’ age and data concerning their current job(s) need to be collected.
Hypotheses 1 to 4 will be tested by independent samples t-test (one-tailed).

q22.value: Only participants who meet the criteria for participation in the study will be included in the data analysis (see data collection procedures). For example, we will exclude people who are under the age of 18 or did voluntary work for less than six months.

q23.value: Only people who have answered at least all items from one scale are included.

attributes.title: Biomechanical comparison of polyaxial locking constructs with and without locking plugs in a fracture gap model.

summary.value: All samples were tested using material test system machine (Instron 6025 processor, High Wycombe, UK d EIR, model LE-05, Irwin, PA, USAe Clarke Ltd. UK).

registration_responses.summary: All samples were tested using material test system machine (Instron 6025 processor, High Wycombe, UK d EIR, model LE-05, Irwin, PA, USAe Clarke Ltd. UK).

q3.value:
Does reciprocity create fitness interdependence?

Many close relationships are grounded in interdependence (i.e. mating relationships, friendships, coalitions etc.). This experiment will test whether superficial reciprocal relationships are enough to produce interdependence. If true, this will provide evidence that reciprocity creates a vested stake in your partner, and thus can help to promote cooperation. 

A key distinguishing factor between a relationship only concerned with direct reciprocity as compared to one grounded in interdependence is the willingness to help when it cannot be repaid. We hypothesize that a reciprocal relationship will foster interdependence and thus a willingness to help a partner even when that help is given anonymously. Specifically, people will be more willing to pay to help a partner if that means increasing the probability of keeping them around.

q4.value:
Main Predictions

1.	We predict the greatest amount of help to be given in cooperative dyads (groups that have cooperated in 3 or more of the proceeding 5 rounds) when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival. This is relative to help given in both cooperative and uncooperative dyads (groups that have defected in 3 or more of the proceeding 5 rounds) when help increases the monetary payoff for the partner, as well as uncooperative dyads when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival.

2.	We predict that individuals that report more perceived interdependence with their partner (example: “What was good for my partner was good for me”) will be more likely to pay to help their partner. This will be true when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival and when help increases the monetary payoff for their partner. 

Secondary Predictions 

1.	We predict that individuals that report more perceived interdependence with their partner will behave more cooperatively in the prisoner’s dilemma game.

Exploratory Predictions

1.	We predict that in uncooperative dyads more help will be given if it directly impacts the probability of the partners survival compared to when help increases the monetary payoff for the partner.  

2.	We predict that if the partner cooperates in the round proceeding the opportunity to help this will increase the likelihood of help being given.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Procedure

This study will be conducted online on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will play a 7 round prisoners dilemma game in partners.

Following the 5th round of the game one of the participants in the dyad will be given an anonymous opportunity to help. The specifics of this opportunity vary by condition:

Control Condition: Would you like to pay 3¢ to increase your partners final earnings by 7¢?

Interdependence Condition: Your partner has a 10% chance of surviving into the next round. If your partner survives, you will both continue to the next round. If your partner does not survive, then there will be no more rounds because you will have no one to interact with. Would you like to pay 3¢ to increase your partners chance of survival from 10% to 90%?

We chose these ratios (3¢ to 7¢ and 3¢ to an 80% increase in survival) to be roughly equivalent in terms of their effects on one’s partner. Because cooperative partners earn 4¢/round, an 80% increased chance of survival results is worth an expected 3.2¢/round, which across two rounds equals 6.4¢ to one’s partner. This is slightly less than the 7¢ to one’s partner in the Control Condition, but that works against our hypothesis because it makes people less likely to give in the Interdependence Condition. 

Exit Survey: 

At the conclusion of the study all participants will respond to demographic questions and a comprehension check. They will also respond to four Likert scale questions (-3 strongly disagree to +3 strongly agree) to measure their perceived level of interdependence with their partner. 

Comprehension check: if you were playing one (and only one) round of this game, what option would give you the highest expected payoff?

Only the partners who did not get an opportunity to help during the game will respond to a hypothetical opportunity to help:
-	Control Condition: Imagine you were still playing the game and you had the opportunity to pay 3¢ to increase your partners final earnings by 7¢, would you?
-	Interdependence Condition: Imagine you were still playing the game and your partner only had a 10% chance of surviving into the next round, but you could pay 3¢ to give them a 90% chance of surviving. If they survived, you would both continue to the next round. If they did not survive, then there would be no more rounds because you'd have no one to interact with. Would you have been willing to pay 3¢ to increase their probability of survival from 10% to 90%?

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants: we will collect data from our game hosted on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will be recruited from the pool of Amazon Mechanical Turk workers. 

Compensation: all participants receive a base pay of $1 USD, and can earn additional money based on their choices and their partners choices in the game (expected range: $1 - $1.73).

q13.value: We will conduct a pilot study to provide estimates for our power analysis. This will determine the minimum number of participants we will run.

question.value: Condition (Control, Interdependence)

Dyad Classification (Cooperative, Uncooperative) 
Help provided (Yes, No) 
Total score on the four measures of interdependence (-3 strongly disagree to +3 strongly agree)
Cooperate or Defect in Preceding Round (C, D) 
Proportion of non-immediately-preceding rounds that are cooperative
Proportion of the total rounds of the prisoner’s dilemma game that cooperation is selected

Analyses

We will use log linear analyses and logistic regressions (see analysis for each question). 

Notes:

-	We will only analyze real helping decisions with consequences (i.e., that actually confer money or probability of survival); we will exclude hypothetical responses unless otherwise specified
-	Cooperative dyads will be categorized as those that have cooperated in more than half of the first 5 rounds. Uncooperative dyads will be categorized as those that have defected in more than half of the first 5 rounds.
-	For cooperation at the individual level, cooperation will be any instance in which they have cooperated irrespective of their partners choice
-	For cooperation at the level of the dyad a cooperative round requires both participants to cooperate. If one or both partners defect that round is categorized as uncooperative 

Log linear analysis:
-	It will have a minimum of 40 observations to ensure at least 5 times the number of cases as there are cells in the data 
-	If the expected frequency of any individual cell is less than one or if the combination of any two cells is less than 5, we will collapse the cooperative/uncooperative dyad grouping into the condition and run a chi-squared analysis to preserve power

Logistic regression:
-	We will test for multicollinearity by calculating a variance inflation factor. If this factor is greater than 5, we will combine the highly related variables for the analysis

Main Analyses

1.	Are superficial reciprocal relationships enough to establish interdependence?

Prediction: If reciprocity creates interdependence, cooperative partners will be more willing to pay a personal cost to anonymously increase their partners chance of survival. This will be greater relative to cooperative dyads whose help only increases their partner’s final payout (i.e., but not the partner’s survival), and all uncooperative dyads.

Variables:
-	Condition (Control, Interdependence) (Categorical)
-	Dyad Classification (Cooperative, Uncooperative) (Categorical)

Outcome Variable:
-	Help provided (Yes, No) (Categorical)

Analyses:
A log linear analysis will be conducted to determine the distribution of help provided in the control and interdependence conditions for cooperative and uncooperative dyads. We will test for main effects of condition and dyad classification, as well as whether there is an interaction. 

Confirmatory Analyses
To test the robustness of this effect we will run the same analysis with the inclusion of the hypothetical data from the other participant. 

2.	Does the perception of interdependence and reciprocity predict a willingness to help a partner?

Prediction: If the perception of interdependence and reciprocity is driving the willingness to help, participants who choose to help will report greater perceptions of interdependence and cooperate more frequently. 

Variables: 

Predictor Variables:
-	Total score on the four measures of interdependence (-3 strongly disagree to +3 strongly agree) (Continuous) 
-	Proportion of the total rounds of the prisoner’s dilemma game that cooperation is selected (Continuous)
-	Condition (Control, Interdependence) (Categorical)

Outcome Variable:
-	Help provided (Yes, No) (Categorical)

Analyses
A logistic regression will be run to test whether the effect of condition, perception of interdependence, and cooperation significantly predict whether the individual chooses to help. 

Confirmatory Analyses
To test the robustness of this effect we will run the same analysis with the inclusion of the hypothetical data from the other participant. 

Secondary Analyses

1.	Does the perception of interdependence increase cooperation?

Prediction: If the perception of interdependence increases cooperation, we predict a positive correlation between reported interdependence and proportion of total rounds of the game that are cooperative. 

Variables:
-	Total score on the four measures of interdependence (-3 strongly disagree to +3 strongly agree) (Continuous)
-	Proportion of the total rounds of the prisoner’s dilemma game that cooperation is selected (Continuous)

Analyses
The above variables will be used to compute a Pearson’s correlation to determine the strength of the correlation between perceptions of interdependence and cooperation. 

Confirmatory Analyses
To further test the robustness of this effect we will run the same analysis at the level of the dyad. This will be done by pooling the overall interdependence score and proportion of total rounds that are cooperative. We will then compute a Pearson’s correlation to determine the strength of the relationship between interdependence and cooperation.

q22.value: Participants who fail the comprehension check will not be included in analyses.

q24.value:
Exploratory Analyses:

1.	Is there value in helping an uncooperative partner?

Prediction: 
If there is no opportunity to interact with new partners, keeping an uncooperative partner can be better than nothing at all. Therefore, we predict that within uncooperative dyads they will be more likely to help when it directly impacts the probability of the partners survival than if it increases the partners final earnings. 

Variables:
-	Condition (Control, Interdependence) (Categorical)
-	Help provided (Yes, No) (Categorical)

Analyses
A chi-square analysis will be run to determine whether uncooperative partners will be more willing to help a partner in the interdependence condition relative to the control condition.

Confirmatory Analyses
To test the robustness of this effect we will run the same analysis with the inclusion of the hypothetical data from the other participant. 

2.	Does a partner’s most recent decision to cooperate or defect have an impact on the decision to help?

Prediction: The choice of a partner to cooperate or defect immediately preceding the opportunity to help will impact the decision. We predict that cooperation in the round immediately prior will increase the likelihood of help being anonymously provided. 

Predictor Variables: 
-	Condition (Control, Interdependence) (Categorical)
-	Proportion of non-immediately-preceding rounds that are cooperative (Continuous)
-	Cooperate or Defect in Preceding Round (C, D) (Categorical)

Outcome Variable:
-	Help provided (Yes, No) (Categorical)

Analyses
A logistic regression will be run to test whether the effect of condition, dyads level of cooperation, and partners decision in the preceding round significantly predicts whether the participant chooses to help independently of each other. 

Confirmatory Analyses
To test the robustness of this effect we will run the same analysis with the inclusion of the hypothetical data from the other participant.

registration_responses.q3:
Does reciprocity create fitness interdependence?

Many close relationships are grounded in interdependence (i.e. mating relationships, friendships, coalitions etc.). This experiment will test whether superficial reciprocal relationships are enough to produce interdependence. If true, this will provide evidence that reciprocity creates a vested stake in your partner, and thus can help to promote cooperation. 

A key distinguishing factor between a relationship only concerned with direct reciprocity as compared to one grounded in interdependence is the willingness to help when it cannot be repaid. We hypothesize that a reciprocal relationship will foster interdependence and thus a willingness to help a partner even when that help is given anonymously. Specifically, people will be more willing to pay to help a partner if that means increasing the probability of keeping them around.
registration_responses.q4:
Main Predictions

1.	We predict the greatest amount of help to be given in cooperative dyads (groups that have cooperated in 3 or more of the proceeding 5 rounds) when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival. This is relative to help given in both cooperative and uncooperative dyads (groups that have defected in 3 or more of the proceeding 5 rounds) when help increases the monetary payoff for the partner, as well as uncooperative dyads when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival.

2.	We predict that individuals that report more perceived interdependence with their partner (example: “What was good for my partner was good for me”) will be more likely to pay to help their partner. This will be true when help directly impacts the probability of the partners survival and when help increases the monetary payoff for their partner. 

Secondary Predictions 

1.	We predict that individuals that report more perceived interdependence with their partner will behave more cooperatively in the prisoner’s dilemma game.

Exploratory Predictions

1.	We predict that in uncooperative dyads more help will be given if it directly impacts the probability of the partners survival compared to when help increases the monetary payoff for the partner.  

2.	We predict that if the partner cooperates in the round proceeding the opportunity to help this will increase the likelihood of help being given.

q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

attributes.title: Psychometric validation of selected questionnaires within the Czech language
attributes.description: Psychometric evaluation of the Czech version of CPAQ and CPAQ-8

q1.value: Psychometric Evaluation of the Czech Version of Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire (CPAQ-20) and its short version (CPAQ-8)

q3.value: The main goal of the study is focused on the psyhcometric validation of Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire (CPAQ) and its short-form CPAQ-8 in the Czech language. Clinical dataset of patients suffering medically unexplained physical symptoms, as well as other patients from psychosomatic clinics will be compared with a non-clinical dataset of general population paired by gender, age, and education to the clinical sample. There are several validation studies of CPAQ in the research literature, however, this will be the first validation study using Czech translation, as far as we know. Moreover, the previously recommended two-dimensional factor structure is somehow questionable. We would like to provide a more methodologically sound psychometric evaluation, with regard to the limits of the previous studies using CPAQ (e.g. testing for the two-dimensional solution with orthogonal rotation using only a principal component analysis, rather than a proper factor analysis).

q4.value:
Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire (CPAQ) and its short version (CPAQ-8) will have a stable two-dimensional underlying factor structure, representing Activity engagement and Pain willingness domains with acceptable fit. 
Additionally, other potentially relevant factor structure models will be tested (i.e. unidimensional, CPAQ-19 without item 16 etc.)
In case of none of the models will provide factor structure with acceptable fit, an exploratory factor analysis with oblique rotation would be estimated.
The factor structure is expected to be invariant across gender, age and clinical and non-clinical sample.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study posess a cross-sectional between-subjects design applied to psychometrically validate the factor structure of CPAQ among two groups (clinical and non-clinical).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Clinical sample: 450 participants from 12 sites were collected during 2018-2018. Data were double-coded from paper-pencil form to the PC-form and a comparison between both coders were made, resulting in more than 50,000 differences. These differences were manually investigated and removed. Final dataset is still in the process of collecting (several information about demografic data from participants is still missing and will be provided by psychosomatic clinics as soon as possible)

Non-clinical sample: not existing yet

question.value:
Clinical sample: 450 participants were recruited within 12 psychosomatic clinics in Czech republic. The data are part of the bigger project (participants were measured every week during the whole therapy up to 12 weeks). For psychometric validations of selected questionnaires only a data from a baseline measurement will be used.

Non-clinical sample: data will be paired by age, gender, and education level to the clinical participants case-by-case. Data will be collected via online survey platform.

q13.value:
clinical sample: 450 participants

non-clinical sample: 450 participants

q14.value: Clinical dataset was already collected, and even though the dataset file is not finished yet, no other participant will be added to the pool. This sample size should be satisfactory to investigate the underlying factor structure of  20 items (at least 20 cases per item).

question.value:
The whole dataset contains all 20 items from CPAQ-20, representing activity engagement and pain willingness.
Other variables: only demographic variables for testing the differences and measurement invariance.

The CPAQ item variables are using the seven-item Likert scale (0-6). According to the original version (McCracken et al., 2004), Activity engagement consists of 11 items, and Pain willingness of 9 items (these are negatively keyed and need to be reversed).

We will use the ordinal confirmatory factor analysis with WLSMV estimator.
Fit indices: Chí-squared, AIC, BIC, RMSEA, SRMR, TLI, CFI (acceptable fit according to Hu & Bentler, 1995)

We will use the confirmatory factor analysis (potentially also exploratory factor analysis if the factor structure specified by predefined models will not provide acceptable fit) or mathematically equivalent analyses, e.g. confirmatory or exploratory multidimensional item response theory. 
We will use the statistical software R for the computational purposes.

q20.value: Pain willingness subscale from CPAQ will be reversed. All the items are originaly negatively keyed.

q22.value: Outliers according to the Mahalanobis distance will be excluded from analyses as well as participants with missing data.

q23.value: Cases with missing data will be tested using a t-test for differences from cases without missing data.

q24.value: Exploratory factor analysis will be conducted only in case of none of the factor structure models specified by the previous research literature will have acceptable fit.

q25.value: The previous literature regarding psychometric validation of the CPAQ will be scanned and potentially relevant factor structure models extracted from these studies will be tested together with the unidimensional and two-factor model. The model fit as well as theoretical support for each model will be compared and discussed.
